{{Infobox Christian denomination |imagewidth= |name = American Association of Lutheran Churches |image = Americanassociationoflutheranchurcheslogo.jpg |caption = |main_classification = [[Protestant]] |orientation = |theology = |polity = [[Congregationalist polity|congregationalist]] polity |leader = |founded_date = 1987 |founded_place = |parent = |merger = |separated_from = [[American Lutheran Church]] |separations = |associations = |footnotes = |congregations = 67 (2014) |members = 16,000 (2008) |website = [http://www.taalc.org/ www.taalc.org] }} '''The American Association of Lutheran Churches''' (TAALC, also known as The AALC) is an American [[Lutheran]] church body. It was formed on November 7, 1987 as a continuation of the [[American Lutheran Church]] (ALC) denomination, the majority of which merged with two other Lutheran church bodies, the [[Lutheran Church in America]] (LCA) and the [[Association of Evangelical Lutheran Churches]] (AELC), to form the [[Evangelical Lutheran Church in America]]. The AALC offices were located in [[Bloomington, Minnesota]]. The national office moved to [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]] in 2007. It has 67 congregations, with about 16,000 members, in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thearda.com/denoms/D_1414.asp|title=American Association of Lutheran Churches|publisher=Association of Religion Data Archives|accessdate=22 February 2012}}</ref> Its current Presiding Pastor is the Rev. Dr. Curtis E. Leins.
==Historical Background== {{Lutheranism in the United States|expanded=alc}} The AALC began with 12 congregations and has, as of 2008, grown to 70 congregations spread across 23 states. The AALC sees itself as a confessional Lutheran Church body in the United States. At its beginning, TAALC defined itself by what it saw as maintaining a commitment to the authority of Holy Scripture and the teaching of the Lutheran confessions by way of retaining the Confession of Faith of the American Lutheran Church.
The AALC operates its own seminary, The [[American Lutheran Theological Seminary]] (ALTS), originally located in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota]]. In the fall of 2005, ALTS relocated to [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]] and is hosted by [[Concordia Theological Seminary]] of the [[Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod]] (LCMS).
The AALC holds to the inerrancy of scripture. It does not ordain women as pastors. However, women may serve as deaconesses. The AALC has two paths to ordination. Besides in congregations, its rostered pastors also serve as chaplains in the U.S. Armed Services, hospitals, correctional facilities, law enforcement, hospice, and a host of other specialized ministries.{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}}
Two AALC pastors are well known within confessional Lutheranism: Chris Rosebrough of Pirate Christian Radio and Jordan Cooper, who is an author, conference speaker, and host of the Just and Sinner podcasts. The AALC is also the denominational home of Trinity Lutheran Church of San Pedro, California, which was a key church in the Lutheran Renewal movement in the 60's under the leadership of the Rev. Larry Christensen.{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}}
==Fellowship with the Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod== Since 1989 representatives of The AALC and the [[Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod]] (LCMS) have met in a series of official and unofficial talks. After six official meetings, at which various doctrinal papers were submitted, representatives of both The AALC and the LCMS have recommended to their respective church bodies that they enter into [[altar and pulpit fellowship]] with one another. The proposal was brought before theology/doctrine commissions of each church body before being presented at their respective national conventions. During the June 20–23, 2007 TAALC National Convention, the AALC declared fellowship with the LCMS; and voted to join the [[International Lutheran Council]] (ILC). On July 16, 2007, the LCMS declared fellowship with the AALC during the LCMS 63rd Regular Convention. The bonds between the two sister churches continue to grow and flourish.
==Basic beliefs of the AALC== (from their Web site)
*Affirms the full authority of the Bible as the inerrant and infallible Word of God *The Lutheran Confessions as a true interpretation of Scripture *A purpose focused on the Great Commission with priority for Evangelism and World Missions *The authority of the local congregation as the basic unit of the church
==Presiding pastors== *Rev. Dr. Duane L. Lindberg 1987–1999 *Rev. Thomas V. Aadland 1999–2007 *Rev. Franklin E. Hays 2007–2014 *Rev. Dr. Curtis E. Leins 2014-
==References== <references/>

Finnish Apostolic Lutheran Congregation (1879–1900s)
Finnish Apostolic Lutheran Church | publications = | website = | slogan = | logo = | footnotes = }} {{Lutheranism in the United States|expanded=awakening}} The '''Apostolic Lutheran Church of America''' (ALCA) is a [[Laestadianism|Laestadian]] [[Lutheran]] [[Christian denominations|church]] denomination established by [[Finnish-Americans|Finnish American]] and Norwegian immigrants in the 1800s. They came mainly from northern [[Finland]] and northern [[Norway]] where they had been members of the state churches. Most or all members had ties from their home countries to the [[Laestadianism|Laestadian]] revival movement named after [[Church of Sweden|Swedish state church]] administrator and pastor [[Lars Levi Laestadius]] of [[Pajala]], [[Sweden]]. Eventually, there were too many arguments between this denomination and the other American [[Laestadianism|Laestadians]], and some of the followers of Laestadius were excluded from the sacrament of holy communion. Under the lead of Salomon Korteniemi, the excluded members formed a congregation of their own in December 1872, under the name the '''Salomon Korteniemi Lutheran Society'''. In 1879 this name was changed to the '''Finnish Apostolic Lutheran Congregation'''. As other congregations of Finns in [[Massachusetts]], [[Michigan]], [[Minnesota]], and [[Oregon]] were organized on the same basis, they came into fellowship with this body under the name the '''Finnish Apostolic Lutheran Church''', or, as it is usually called, the Apostolic Lutheran Church. The ALCA Laestadians are called "Mickelsens" by other Laestadians, after 20th Century leader Reverend Andrew Mickelsen (1897-1983).https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/75093116http://extoots.blogspot.fi/2008/08/sports-good-thing_05.html The organization is also referred to by members and non-members as the Federation. == Membership == In 2009, membership in the denomination was estimated to include 6,000 baptized members.[http://www.lutheranworld.org/LWF_Documents/LWF-Statistics-2009.pdf LWF Statistics 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100821080424/http://www.lutheranworld.org/LWF_Documents/LWF-Statistics-2009.pdf |date=2010-08-21 }} Its ministers are mostly lay preachers.[http://clclutheran.org/atlanta/bibleclass/Lutheranchurches.pdf A Brief Study of the Lutheran Churches in America] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101121161735/http://clclutheran.org/atlanta/bibleclass/Lutheranchurches.pdf |date=2010-11-21 }} It has sizable congregations in [[Michigan]], [[Minnesota]], [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]], [[New Hampshire]] and in various other countries, such as [[Canada]] and [[Finland]]. The national organization is governed by an elected board (the Central Board) which meets regularly at various locations across the United States and [[Canada]], and individual member churches are governed by elected boards. The ALCA has no central headquarters facility. == Doctrine == [[File:Amerikan lestadiolaisuuden sukupuu_eng2.png|thumb|Family tree of laestadianism in America. Includes defunct groups.]] The ALCA narrowly follows the doctrines and practices of [[Laestadianism]]. For example, it emphasizes the necessity of regeneration and the practical importance of absolution from [[sin]]. It follows the Laestadian-specific doctrine of the [[Laestadianism#Declaration of forgiveness|audible declaration of forgiveness of sins]] and encourages avoidance of worldliness and sin. Unlike the two larger branches of Laestadianism, the ALCA does not teach that it is the [[Laestadianism#Exclusion and inclusion among Laestadian sub-groups|only true Laestadian group]]. Liturgically, the church accepts the creeds of the Evangelical [[Lutheran]] church. The majority of the written doctrine of the Apostolic Lutheran Church is based on [[Luther's Small Catechism]], a collection of [[Martin Luther]]'s teachings. == References == {{Reflist}} * Encyclopedia of American Religions, J. Gordon Melton, editor. 6th Ed., 1999. pp 93–94. == External links == * [http://www.apostoliclutheran.org/ Official Website] * [http://www.laestadiustexter.se Sermons of Laestadius] {{DEFAULTSORT:Apostolic Lutheran Church Of America}} [[Category:Evangelicalism]] [[Category:Laestadianism]] [[Category:Lutheran denominations in North America]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1872]] [[Category:Lutheran denominations established in the 19th century]] [[Category:Finnish-American history]] [[Category:Sami-American history]] [[Category:1872 establishments in the United States]] {{Lutheran-stub}}

[[Plymouth, Minnesota]] 55441 | origin_link = | founder = | founded_date = 1962 | founded_place = | separated_from = [[Lutheran Free Church]] | parent = | merger = | absorbed = | separations = | merged_into = | defunct = | congregations_type = | congregations = 280 (2009) | members = 44,473 (2009) | ministers_type = | ministers = 277 (2009) | missionaries = | churches = | hospitals = | nursing_homes = | aid = | primary_schools = | secondary_schools = | tax_status = | tertiary = | other_names = | publications = | website = {{url|www.AFLC.org}} | slogan = | logo = | footnotes = }} {{Lutheranism in the United States|expanded=alc}} '''Association of Free Lutheran Congregations''' is the sixth largest [[Lutheran]] church body in the [[United States]]. The AFLC includes congregations from the former [[Lutheran Free Church]] before 1963, in 27 different states, as well as four [[Canadian province]]s. The AFLC is not an incorporated [[synod]], but a free association. Each local congregation is a separate corporation. [[Minnesota]] is the geographic center of the organization, with over 80 congregations and over 12,000 members.{{cite web|url = http://www.thearda.com/mapsReports/maps/map.asp?variable=67&state=101&variable2=| title = 2000 Religious Congregations and Membership Study|publisher = Glenmary Research Center|accessdate = 2009-12-04}} There are also numerous congregations in the neighboring states of [[North Dakota]], [[South Dakota]], and [[Wisconsin]]. The AFLC headquarters are in [[Plymouth, Minnesota]] along with the [[Association Free Lutheran Bible School and Seminary]]. The AFLC logo is the open Bible that is symbolic of God's word as the foundation of faith and life. The Ascending Dove is symbolic of the freedom of congregation, and the power and guidance of the Holy Spirit. The Green Vine is symbolic of the living congregation bearing fruit for God. ==History== The AFLC was formed by 40 churches in 1962. The churches that formed the AFLC were members of the former [[Lutheran Free Church]] who did not wish to join [[The American Lutheran Church]] in 1963, an earlier merged multi-ethnic denomination formed in 1960. The body was originally called the '''Lutheran Free Church-not merged'''. The ALC filed suit against the group for using the name Lutheran Free Church. By 1964, the name Association of Free Lutheran Congregations was chosen. In 2006, the AFLC had 43,360 baptized members in 267 churches.{{cite web|url = http://www.thearda.com/Denoms/D_1302.asp| title = 2008 ''Yearbook of American & Canadian Churches''|publisher = The National Council of Churches|accessdate = 2009-12-04}} In 2009, the AFLC had 277 pastors, 280 congregations, and 44,473 members.{{cite web|title=Lutheran Free Church|url=http://www.thearda.com/Denoms/D_885.asp|work=American Denomination Profiles|publisher=[[Association of Religion Data Archives]]|accessdate=July 27, 2017}} ==Doctrine== The AFLC accept and believe in the Holy Bible as the complete written Word of God, preserved by the Holy Spirit for salvation and instruction. The AFLC accepts the ancient ecumenical symbols, namely, the [[Apostles Creed|Apostles]], the [[Nicene Creed|Nicene]], and the [[Athanasian Creed]]s; [[Luther's Small Catechism]] and the unaltered [[Augsburg Confession]] as the true expression of the Christian faith and life. Five principal reasons for the formation of the AFLC: *Recognizes the [[Bible]] as the inspired and inerrant authority in all matters of faith and life. *Recognizes that the teaching and preaching of God's Word is the main task of the Church, to be conducted in such a way that the saints are built up and unbelievers see their need for salvation. *Believes that the congregation is the right form of the Kingdom of God on earth, with no authority above it but the Word and the Spirit of God; *Believes that [[Christian]] unity is a spiritual concept, not a man-made organization such as the [[World Council of Churches]] or the [[National Council of Churches]]. *Believes that [[Christianity|Christians]] are called to be a salt and light, separated from the ways of the world, and that this difference is to be reflected in the life of the congregation as well as in the institutions of the church body. The AFLC allows [[open communion]] and [[women's suffrage]] in congregational voting.[http://clclutheran.org/atlanta/bibleclass/Lutheranchurches.pdf A Brief Study of the Lutheran Churches in America] ==Committees and corporations== The AFLC has five corporations that are sponsored by the AFLC to direct their common endeavors: the Coordinating Committee, the Schools Corporation, the Missions Corporation, the AFLC Foundation and the Association Retreat Center (ARC. There are two auxiliary corporations in the AFLC: the Women's Missionary Federation (WMF) and Free Lutheran Youth (FLY). ===Coordinating Committee=== The coordinating committee consists of seven members from the congregations currently part of the AFLC. The main duties of the coordinating committee includes monitoring the pastoral roster, monitoring the congregational roster, and providing guidance for the other ministries of the AFLC, including youth, evangalism, parish education, etc. ===Schools Corporation=== The schools corporation's main delegation is the election of the board of trustees, which governs the [[Association Free Lutheran Bible School and Seminary]] (AFLBS). This corporation consists of fifty members from the congregations of the AFLC. The AFLC leaders came to the consensus to create a Lutheran Bible School patterned after the fundamental teachings of the [[Golden Valley Lutheran College|Lutheran Bible Institute]] founded in 1919. The school was opened in 1966 with 13 students but grew to 35 the next year. By the 1990s, the AFLBS was averaging 105 students. Today there are approximately 200 students attending the school. ===Missions Corporation=== The missions corporation consists of one hundred members of the congregations of the AFLC, and elects from itself a World Missions Committee and a Home Missions Committee, which are involved in the outreach of the AFLC into the [[United States of America|United States]] and several other countries. ===AFLC Foundation=== ===Association Retreat Center=== The '''Association Retreat Center (ARC)''' is a separate organization of the AFLC near [[Osceola, Wisconsin]] that serves as a retreat center for various activities within the AFLC. ===Other Committees/Corporations=== The '''Women's Missionary Federation (WMF)''' serves the women of the churches with [[Bible]] studies, fellowship, and has an emphasis on missionary services. The '''Free Lutheran Youth (FLY)''', is a youth organization dealing with youth ministry. ==Publications== The official publication of the AFLC is "The Lutheran Ambassador", with twelve issues per year devoted to Bible-centered articles and news of the churches. Ambassador Publications is the parish education department of the AFLC. The "Ambassador Hymnal" is the [[hymnal]] published by the AFLC, which contains over 600 hymns as well as selected order of church services and responsive Bible readings. ==Presidents of the AFLC== {| class="wikitable" !Name !Term |- |John P. Strand |1962-1978 |- |Richard Snipstead |1978-1992 |- |Robert L. Lee |1992-2007 |- |Elden K. Nelson |2007-2013 |- |Lyndon Korhonen |2013- |- |} ==Annual Conferences== The AFLC schedules each year a conference to share reports of congregations and other various ministries. The main reason for these conferences is spiritual edification, as the schedules include prayer times, worship hours, and business meetings together. It is here that suggestions to changes are presented and discussed. It is also here that the elections for positions in committees/corporations are made. {{Div col|rules=no|gap=2em|small=yes|colwidth=15em}} *1963 Fargo, North Dakota *1964 Valley City, North Dakota {{COI|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox Christian denomination | name = Augustana Catholic Church | image = Alcc logo.gif | imagewidth = 150px | caption = Official logo | main_classification = [[Lutheran]] | orientation = [[Evangelical Catholic]] | polity = [[Episcopal polity|Episcopal]] | founder = [[Irl A. Gladfelter]] | founded_date = 1997 | founded_place = [[Kansas City, Missouri]] | separated_from = | parent = [[Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod]] | merger = Athanasian Catholic Church of the Augsburg Confession | separations = | associations = [[Augustana Catholic Communion]] | area = | congregations = | members = | footnotes = }} {{Lutheranism in the United States|expanded=high_church}} The '''Augustana Catholic Church''' (ACC), formerly the '''Anglo-Lutheran Catholic Church''' (ALCC) and the '''Evangelical Community Church-Lutheran''' (ECCL), is an American [[Church body|church]] in the [[Lutheran]] [[Evangelical Catholic]] tradition. The ACC says it is unique among Lutheran churches in that it is of both Lutheran and Anglo-Catholic heritage and has also been significantly influenced by the Roman Catholic Church. The church was founded in 1997 by former members of the [[Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod]]. Its headquarters are in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{citation | url = http://anglolutherancatholic.org/offices/international-headquarters | title = International Headquarters|publisher = The Anglo-Lutheran Catholic Church}}.</ref> The ACC has long had a policy of seeking union with the Catholic Church and announced in 2011 that it would accept the conditions of ''[[Anglicanorum coetibus]]'' and join the [[personal ordinariate]]s as they are established. Later developments on limitations of joining the ordinariate caused the ACC to hold their offer while they established intercommunion with groups such as the [[Old Roman Catholic Church of North America]]. The Church claims a membership in excess of 60,000 in 12 countries.<ref>[http://www.augustanacatholicchurch.co/about-us.html Augustana Catholic Church website]</ref>
==Doctrine== The Augustana Catholic Church considers Lutherans to be Catholics in a temporary involuntary [[Schism (religion)|schism]] imposed on it by the Roman Catholic Church when [[Martin Luther]]'s attempt to start a renewal movement within Roman Catholicism slipped out of his control.<ref>{{citation | quote = In its first phase, up to the Confession of Augsburg, which was the first synthesis of Lutheranism, Protestantism had no idea of developing into a church other than that of all time, the Catholic Church centered on the See of Rome | first = Louis | last = Bouyer | author-link = Louis Bouyer | title = The Spirit and Forms of Protestantism | page = 268 | place = Princeton, NJ | publisher = Scepter Publishers | year = 2001 | origyear = 1956}}.</ref><ref>{{citation | quote = Luther's basic intuition [the gratuitousness of salvation], on which Protestantism continually draws for its abiding vitality, so far from being difficult to reconcile with Catholic tradition or inconsistent with the teaching of the apostles, was a return to the clearest elements of their teaching and is in the most direct line of that tradition… Protestantism, reduced to what Protestants themselves regard as its essence, was under no necessity to embody itself in schism and heresy… Considered in itself and in the natural course of its development, [the basic principle of the Reformation] does not lead to division and error. These are only the accidental results of the Reformation… [T]he schisms and heresies of the sixteenth century resulted not from the initial impulse but from external and adventitious factors that disturbed its development | page = 62 | first = Louis | last = Bouyer | author-link = Louis Bouyer | title = The Spirit and Forms of Protestantism | place = Princeton, NJ | publisher = Scepter Publishers | year = 2001 | origyear = 1956}}.</ref><ref>{{citation | first = Ells L "Skip" | last = Knox | publisher = Boise State University | url = http://www.boisestate.edu/courses/reformation/luther/29.shtml | title = Martin Luther: Conclusions}}.</ref><ref>{{cite book | last=Marius | first=Richard | year=1999 | title=Martin Luther: the Christian between God and Death | publisher=[[Belknap Press]] | location=Cambridge MA | ISBN= 0-674-00387-X | pages= 434, 434–35, 472, 474, 480, 483}}</ref> The ACC teaches that Lutheranism in general is a form of non-Roman Catholicism, and considers the other Lutheran churches to be "[[Protestant]]" only to the extent that they have accepted insights from the [[Calvinist]] and [[Zwinglian]] phases of the [[Protestant Reformation|Reformation]].<ref>{{citation | last = Zip | title = US Lutheran Web Links | url = http://www.pastorzip.org/uslutheranlinx.html#evancath | chapter = Evangelical Catholics}}.</ref>
The Augustana Catholic Church accepts the [[Augsburg Confession Variata|Unaltered]] [[Augsburg Confession]],<ref>For a discussion of prospects for some kind of Roman Catholic recognition of the Augsburg Confession, see [[Richard John Neuhaus]], [http://theologytoday.ptsem.edu/oct1980/v37-3-article1.htm "Augsburg and Catholicism: Healing the Reformation Breach,"] ''[[Theology Today]]'' 37, no. 3 (Oct. 1980): 294–305. "In 1974 the idea was first advanced that the Roman Catholic Church should 'recognize' the Augsburg Confession. It received wider attention when Joseph Ratzinger, now Cardinal Archbishop of Munich, took up the possibility of a 'Catholic recognition of the Augsburg Confession or, more correctly, of recognizing the Augsburg Confession as Catholic.'" Neuhaus concluded: "There will be no one act of reunion between the Roman Catholic Church and the Lutheran Church; there will at some point be a favorable response from a Lutheran church or churches. With that initiating reunion, the situation of all of Lutheranism will have changed. Lutherans who then care to maintain fellowship with other Lutherans will be inclined, if not compelled, to act out the logic that is inherent in the already prevailing consensus that the interim church called Lutheran must pursue its destiny as a movement for all the church in the healing of the breach of the sixteenth century.”</ref><ref>Paul A. Schreck, "Under one Christ: implications of a Roman Catholic recognition of the Confessio Augustana in CE 2017," ''Journal of Ecumenical Studies'' 43, no. 1 (Winter 2008): 90–110.</ref> the [[Apology of the Augsburg Confession]], and Martin Luther's [[Small Catechism]], but only insofar as they are in full agreement with Roman Catholic faith and order, doctrines, and traditions. The ACC recognizes the other documents contained in ''[[The Book of Concord]]''—except for the [[Formula of Concord]]—but only insofar as they are in full agreement with Roman Catholic faith, order, doctrines and traditions. It does not accept the Formula of Concord on any level, nor is it bound by any of its terms and provisions, though it does respect it as a historical Lutheran document.<ref>{{citation | title = Anglo-Lutheran Catholic Church | url = http://www.anglolutherancatholic.org/}}.</ref>
The ACC has accepted major modifications in sacramental theology and principles of church government from the [[Church of Sweden]] (Lutheran), the [[Oxford Movement]] of the Anglican Communion, and the documents and teachings of the [[magisterium]] of the Roman Catholic Church which includes the ''[[Catechism of the Catholic Church]]'' (1994).
The ACC says it is unique among Lutheran churches in that it accepts, as additional confessional documents, the [[Thirty-Nine Articles|Articles of Religion]] from the ''[[Book of Common Prayer]]'' as interpreted by [[John Henry Newman]] in ''[[Tracts for the Times]]''<ref>See John Henry Cardinal Newman, [[Tract 90|"Remarks on Certain Passages in the Thirty-Nine Articles,"]] ''Tracts for the Times'', no. XC (1841).</ref> (insofar as they do not conflict with authentic Catholic faith and tradition); the Roman Catholic–Lutheran ''[[Joint Declaration on the Doctrine of Justification]]'' (Augsburg, Germany, 1999);<ref>{{citation | author = Pope Benedict XVI | url = http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/benedict_xvi/audiences/2008/documents/hf_ben-xvi_aud_20081119_en.html | title = The Doctrine of Justification: from Works to Faith | date = 19 November 2008}}.</ref> the [[Catechism of the Catholic Church]]; and the documents and decrees of all [[Ecumenical Council]]s recognized by the Roman Catholic Church. The ACC's strongest connections are with the Roman Catholic Church and some form of visible, corporate unity with that church is the ecumenical goal of the ACC.
Since June 2008, all clergy of the ACC are required to sign a version of the Roman Catholic ''mandatum'',<ref>{{citation | publisher = United States Conference of Catholic Bishops | url = http://www.usccb.org/bishops/guidelines.shtml | title = Guidelines Concerning the Academic Mandatum in Catholic Universities (Canon 812)}}.</ref> a legally binding contract requiring the signatories not to teach, preach, write, or publish anything contrary to the magisterium of the [[Roman Catholic Church]].
The Augustana Catholic Church accepts [[papal primacy]] and [[papal infallibility]] even though it is not under papal control at this time.<ref>{{citation | publisher = Archdiocese of the West | title = Frequently Asked Questions | contribution = How Is The ACC I is Different From Other Lutheran Churches | url = http://www.augustanacatholicchurch.co}}</ref>
The ACC is theologically and socially conservative, with the same view of the nature and authority of [[scripture]] as the Roman Catholic Church as stated in the [[Vatican II]] document, ''The Dogmatic Constitution on Divine Revelation'' - ''[[Dei verbum]]''<ref>{{citation|title=The Dogmatic Constitution on Divine Revelation |url=http://www.vatican.va/archive/hist_councils/ii_vatican_council/documents/vat-ii_const_19651118_dei-verbum_en.html |publisher=The Vatican |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531175312/http://www.vatican.va/archive/hist_councils/ii_vatican_council/documents/vat-ii_const_19651118_dei-verbum_en.html |archivedate=May 31, 2014 }}.</ref> and the Pontifical Biblical Commission's document, ''The Interpretation of the Bible in the Church''.<ref>{{citation | author = Pontifical Biblical Commission | url = http://www.ewtn.com/library/CURIA/PBCINTER.htm | title = The Interpretation of the Bible in the Church | date = March 18, 1994 | publisher = EWTN}}.</ref>
==Worship== The worship of the Augustana Catholic Church is sacramental. It differs from other Lutheran churches by recognizing and celebrating the seven [[sacrament]]s.<ref>{{citation | url = http://www.ewtn.com/library/PAPALDOC/JP2SEVEN.HTM | title = The Seven Sacraments | publisher = EWTN}}.</ref> The primary [[liturgy]] of the ACC is from the [[Book of Divine Worship]], a book of rites authorized by the [[Holy See|Vatican]] and used by [[Anglican Use]] parishes of the Roman Catholic Church.<ref>{{citation|title=Book of Divine Worship |url=http://www.atonementonline.com/bodw.php |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090220230316/http://www.atonementonline.com/bodw.php |archivedate=2009-02-20 |df= }}.</ref> Other rites approved and authorized for use by the Roman Catholic Church may also be used by ACC clergy. Anglican, Lutheran, and other Protestant rites are not authorized for use by ACC clergy.<ref>{{citation | url = http://www.ewtn.com/expert/answers/catholic_rites_and_churches.htm | title = Catholic Rites and Churches | publisher = EWTN}}.</ref>
==Polity and organization== The polity of the Augustana Catholic Church is [[Episcopal polity|episcopal]] rather than [[Congregationalist polity|congregationalist]] and follows the model of the Roman Catholic Church. The ACC is governed by a [[Metropolitan Archbishop|metropolitan archbishop]] assisted by a [[vicar general]] and the [[Holy Synod]] (which consists of the bishops of the church and is concerned with matters of doctrine and polity) and the National Standing Committee (which includes lay members and is concerned with temporal administration and finance) and together they comprise the corporate [[Board of Directors]]. The ACC operates in accordance with the 1983 [[Canon law (Catholic Church)#Codification|Code of Canon Law]] of the Roman Catholic Church<ref name="Law">{{citation|url=http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG1104/_INDEX.HTM |title=Code of Canon Law |year=1983 |publisher=The Vatican |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080220062727/http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG1104/_INDEX.HTM |archivedate=February 20, 2008 }}.</ref> in areas not covered by its own canon law code.
The leadership of the Augustana Catholic Church changed on December 1, 2011, with the resignations of its founding metropolitan archbishop and the bishop of the Diocese of Michigan. On December 12, 2011, the Holy Synod (composed of the bishops) of the ACC elected and installed Archbishop Robert W. Edmondson as the church's second metropolitan archbishop.
On 8 April 2012, the ACC underwent a major reorganization by the metropolitan archbishop. It has two dioceses.{{when|date=October 2016}} The Diocese of the Northeast has been renamed the Diocese of the East and given the territory east of the western border of Ontario, Michigan; Ohio, Kentucky, and Tennessee to the Atlantic Ocean; and also given jurisdiction over the Caribbean, Europe, Africa, and South America. The dioceses formerly having jurisdiction over those areas have been suppressed, and its former diocesan bishops given titular dioceses and positions as bishop directors of the various major church-wide offices in the metropolitan archbishop's curia which are identical in scope and authority to the similar dicasteries in the Roman Catholic Church's curia. The Diocese of the West has been given jurisdiction over the rest of the United States including Alaska and Hawaii, Canada, Mexico, and the Caribbean.
On April 24, 2012, Archbishop Edmondson of the Augustana Catholic Church and Archbishop Chris M. Hernandez, Archbishop Co-Adjutor of the North American Old Roman Catholic Church - Utrecht Succession, signed a Concordat of Full Communion and Pledge to Full Unity.
The ACC is a member of the Augustana Catholic Communion, the Sudanese Council of Churches USA and the Sudanese Council of Churches, and is in full communion with the Traditional Church of England, the Anglican Church-Traditional Rite (England, Scotland, and Wales,) the Anglican Church of the Americas, and the North American Old Roman Catholic Church - Utrecht Succession.
==Orders== Where [[ordination]], the priesthood, the episcopacy, and the papacy are concerned, the ACC rejects the teachings of Lutheranism and accepts all the Roman Catholic teachings. Other than not requiring celibacy of its clergy, there are no differences between the teachings of the Roman Catholic Church and those of the ACC regarding the sacrament of [[Holy Orders (Catholic Church)|Holy Orders]].<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.vatican.va/archive/catechism/p2s2c3a6.htm |chapter=The Sacrament of Holy Orders |title=Catechism of the Catholic Church |publisher=The Vatican |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100111024309/http://www.vatican.va/archive/catechism/p2s2c3a6.htm |archivedate=2010-01-11 |df= }}.</ref> All ordinations and re-ordinations - without exception - are performed using the rites of ordination found in the most current edition of the Ordinal from the Pontifical of the Roman Catholic Church set within a celebration of the Roman Missal (Third Edition) or the Mass from the Roman Catholic [[Anglican Use]] ''[[Book of Divine Worship]]'' exclusively, with no additions or deletions apart from the deletion of the celibacy vow in the diaconal ordination rite, with the specific intention that ordination is into a sacrificing (sacerdotal) [[priesthood]]—a ''sacerdotium''—instead of into a ''[[ministerium]]''; admitting, both in theory and in practice, all that is involved in the Catholic doctrine of the ''sacerdotium''.
All clergy entering from other churches who have not been ordained in the historic [[apostolic succession]] must be re-ordained. The clergy of the Augustana Catholic Church have all been ordained (or re-ordained) as deacons, priests and bishops in the historic apostolic succession, which it obtained in 2004 from Archbishop [[Peter Paul Brennan]], [[Order of Corporate Reunion|O.C.R]]. of the Ecumenical Catholic Diocese of the Americas<ref>{{citation | url = http://www.ind-movement.org/denoms/ecda_brennan.html | title = ECDA | publisher = Ind Movement}}.</ref> and Archbishops [[Francis C. Spataro]], O.C.R. and [[Paget E. J. Mack]], O.S.B.M. of the Apostolic Episcopal Church.<ref>{{citation | url = http://www.bertilpersson.com/ | title = Apostolic Episcopal Church}}.</ref> The ACC's primary apostolic lineage is the [[Scipione Rebiba|Rebiban]] or Vatican succession, derived from the Roman Catholic Church through Archbishop [[Carlos Duarte Costa]]<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/bduco.html |title=Episcopal Lineage of Bishop Carlos Duarte Costa |publisher=Catholic Hierarchy |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151002111122/http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/bduco.html |archivedate=October 2, 2015 }}.</ref> and the [[Brazilian Catholic Apostolic Church]] (ICAB). It also holds the [[Gerardus Gul]] lineage of the [[Old Catholic Church of the Netherlands]] among several others.
The Augustana Catholic Church has never had female clergy for the same reasons the Roman Catholic Church rejects the ordination of women,<ref>{{citation | url = http://stmichaelsalcc.org/News.dsp | title = New - St. Michael's Lutheran Church ALCC, Kansas City, Missouri - News - ALCC Official Statement on the Ordination of Women }}.</ref><ref>{{citation|author=Pope John Paul II |url=http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/john_paul_ii/apost_letters/documents/hf_jp-ii_apl_22051994_ordinatio-sacerdotalis_en.html |title=Ordinatio Sacerdotalis |year=1994 |publisher=The Vatican |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120118205206/http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/john_paul_ii/apost_letters/documents/hf_jp-ii_apl_22051994_ordinatio-sacerdotalis_en.html |archivedate=January 18, 2012 }}.</ref> and has placed a moratorium on the ordination of women until such time as it is ordered by a [[Pope]] (for the diaconate) or an [[Ecumenical Council]] (for the priesthood and episcopacy). The ACC has the same policies as the Roman Catholic Church on the ordination of non celibate homosexual persons and the blessing of same-sex unions, permitting neither.<ref>{{citation | url = http://stmichaelsalcc.org/News.dsp | title = New - St. Michael's Lutheran Church ALCC, Kansas City, Missouri - News - ALCC Official Statement on the Ordination of non-Celibate Homosexuals }}.</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.vatican.va/roman_curia/congregations/ccatheduc/documents/rc_con_ccatheduc_doc_20051104_istruzione_en.html |title=Instruction Concerning the Criteria for the Discernment of Vocations with regard to Persons with Homosexual Tendencies in view of their Admission to the Seminary and to Holy Orders |year=2005 |publisher=The Vatican |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080225072042/http://www.vatican.va/roman_curia/congregations/ccatheduc/documents/rc_con_ccatheduc_doc_20051104_istruzione_en.html |archivedate=February 25, 2008 }}.</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.vatican.va/roman_curia/congregations/cfaith/documents/rc_con_cfaith_doc_20030731_homosexual-unions_en.html |title=Considerations Regarding Proposals to Give Legal Recognition to Unions Between Homosexual Persons |year=2003 |publisher=The Vatican |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160613085642/http://www.vatican.va/roman_curia/congregations/cfaith/documents/rc_con_cfaith_doc_20030731_homosexual-unions_en.html |archivedate=2016-06-13 |df= }}.</ref>
==Petition for unity with the Holy See== On May 15, 2009, and again in 2014, the Augustana Catholic Church officially filed a formal petition to enter the Roman Catholic Church "as a unified body" in whichever form the Pope and the Curia decides is the most appropriate. The ACC's petition was filed with the Council for Promoting Christian Unity, and is before the [[Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith]].{{when|date=October 2016}} It is a separate petition from that of the [[Traditional Anglican Communion]].<ref>{{citation | url = http://www.catholic.org/international/international_story.php?id=37315&wf=rsscol | title = Are Lutherans Next? Lutherans Seek Full Communion with Catholic Church | year = 2010 | publisher = Catholic Online}}.</ref><ref>{{citation | url = http://sda2rc.blogspot.com/search?q=Anglo-Lutheran+Catholic | year = 2009 | chapter = Anglo-Lutheran Catholic: Lutheran Catholics? | title = Seventh-day Adventist to Roman Catholic: A Blog of Two Churches}}.</ref><ref>{{citation | url = http://stmichaelsalcc.org/News.dsp | title = The Anglo-Lutheran Catholic Church Has Filed A Petition To Enter the Roman Catholic Church | publisher = St. Michael's Lutheran Church ALCC, Kansas City Missouri}}.</ref>
==Leadership== * The Most Reverend [[Robert W. Edmondson]], Metropolitan Archbishop of the Augustana Catholic Church; Director, Office of the Director of Temporal Administration and Finance; Director, Office of the Director of Military Services and Veteran’s Affairs<ref name="International Headquarters">{{cite web|title=International Headquarters|url=http://anglolutherancatholic.org/administration-and-diocesan-offices/international-headquarters/|publisher=Anglo-Lutheran Catholic Church|accessdate=6 May 2012}}</ref> * The Most Reverend [[Kenneth L. Bakken]], Vicar General of the Augustana Catholic Church<ref name="International Headquarters"/> * The Most Reverend [[Tan Binh Phan Nguyen]], Dean of the Holy Synod; Director, Office of the Vicar General for Vietnamese Churches<ref name="International Headquarters"/> * The Most Reverend [[Thomas Stover]], Bishop, Diocese of the West; Director of Evangelism and Church Growth, Office of the Metropolitan Archbishop<ref name="International Headquarters"/>

Lutherans Seek Full Communion with Catholic Church | year = 2010 | publisher = Catholic Online}}. * {{citation | url = http://sda2rc.blogspot.com/search?q=Anglo-Lutheran+Catholic | year = 2009 | chapter = Anglo-Lutheran Catholic: Lutheran Catholics? | title = Seventh-day Adventist to Roman Catholic: A Blog of Two Churches}}.

{{Infobox Christian denomination | icon = | icon_width = | icon_alt = | name = Canadian Association of Lutheran Congregations | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | imagewidth = | alt = | caption = | abbreviation = | main_classification = [[Lutheranism|Lutheran]] | orientation = | scripture = | theology = | polity = | governance = | structure = | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title1 = | leader_name1 = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | fellowships_type = | fellowships = | fellowships_type1 = | fellowships1 = | division_type = | division = | division_type1 = | division1 = | division_type2 = | division2 = | division_type3 = | division3 = | associations = | area = [[Canada]] | language = | liturgy = | headquarters = | origin_link = | founder = | founded_date = 1992 | founded_place = | separated_from = | parent = | merger = | absorbed = | separations = | merged_into = | defunct = | congregations_type = | congregations = 33 | members = | ministers_type = | ministers = | missionaries = | churches = | hospitals = | nursing_homes = | aid = | primary_schools = | secondary_schools = | tax_status = | tertiary = | other_names = | publications = | website = {{url|www.calc.ca}} | slogan = | logo = | footnotes = }}The '''Canadian Association of Lutheran Congregations''' ('''CALC''') is a small [[Lutheran]] denomination in Canada. Along with the [[Evangelical Lutheran Church in Canada]] and the [[Lutheran Church–Canada]], it is one of only three all-Canadian Lutheran denominations.
==History== CALC was founded in the early 1990s by a group of Lutherans who strove to keep to keep the authority of [[Bible|Scripture]] central to the life of their churches and their faith. It was formally incorporated by an act of parliament in June 1994. It is today the third largest Lutheran denomination in Canada.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://calc.ca/QandA_CALC_Dec_%202014.pdf |format=PDF |title='The Little Lutheran Church That Stood' − Q&A's about the Canadian Association of Lutheran Congregations (CALC) |website=Calc.ca |accessdate=2016-07-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.christlutheranmorden.ca/our-history/ |title=Our History |publisher=Christ Lutheran Church, Morden, Manitoba |access-date=September 10, 2018}}</ref>
==Seminary== The official seminary of CALC is the [[Institute of Lutheran Theology]] (ILT), located in [[Brookings, South Dakota|Brookings]], [[South Dakota]]. In partnership with ILT, it trains all its pastors through a unique program called The Shepherd's Pathway. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.calc.ca/pastoraltraining.htm|title=Canadian Association of Lutheran Congregations - Pastoral Training|website=www.calc.ca}}</ref>
==Membership== From a single congregation in 1992,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://calc.ca/CALC%20History%20Brochure_December%202014.pdf |format=PDF |title=Canadian Association of Lutheran Congregations |website=Calc.ca |accessdate=2016-07-01}}</ref> CALC has grown to include 33 congregations in 5 Canadian provinces. (British Columbia, 6; Alberta, 16; Saskatchewan, 3; Manitoba, 1; Ontario, 7)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://calc.ca/congregations.htm |title=Canadian Association of Lutheran Congregations - Congregations |website=Calc.ca |date= |accessdate=2016-07-01}}</ref> *British Columbia **Basel Hakka Lutheran Church, Vancouver **Grace Lutheran Church Kelowna **Martin Luther Evangelical Lutheran Church, Vancouver **Mount Calvary Lutheran Church, Mission **St. Andrew's Lutheran Church, Kamloops **Vancouver Chinese Lutheran Church, Burnaby *Alberta **Asker Lutheran Church, Ponoka **Bardo Lutheran Church, Tofield **Bethel Lutheran Church, Marwayne **Calvary Evangelical Lutheran Church, Wetaskiwin **Christ Lutheran Church, Sexsmith **Emmaus Lutheran Church, Edmonton **Faith Lutheran Church, Calgary **Golden Valley Lutheran Church, Viking **Immanuel Lutheran Church of Rosenthal, Stony Plain **Journey's Lutheran Church, Grande Prairie **Peace Lutheran Church, Wainwright **Salem Lutheran Church, Kingman **Sharon Lutheran Church, Irma **St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Cochrane **Trondhjem Lutheran Church, Round Hill **Victory Lutheran Church, Medicine Hat *Saskatchewan **Immanuel Lutheran Church, Parkside **St. John North Prairie Lutheran Church, Preeceville **Trinity Lutheran Church, Leader *Manitoba **Christ Lutheran Church, Morden *Ontario **All Saints Lutheran Church, Ottawa **Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd, Toronto **Faith Lutheran Church, North York **Goodwood Uxbridge Lutheran Church, Goodwood **Resurrection Lutheran Church, Pembroke **St. Matthew's Lutheran Church, Cornwall **St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Sullivan

{{Infobox Christian denomination |imagewidth= |name = Church of the Lutheran Brethren of America |image = CLBlogo.jpg |caption = |main_classification = [[Protestant]] |orientation = |theology = Moderate to Conservative |polity = |leader = |founded_date = 1900 |founded_place = [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]] |parent = |merger = |separated from = [[United Norwegian Lutheran Church of America]] |separations = |associations = |footnotes = |congregations = 123 (2009) |members = 8,860 (2009) |website = [http://www.clba.org/ www.clba.org] |headquarters = Fergus Falls, Minnesota }} {{Lutheranism in the United States|expanded=awakening}} The '''Church of the Lutheran Brethren of America (CLBA)''' is a [[Lutheranism|Lutheran]] denomination of [[Christian]]s rooted in a spiritual awakening at the turn of the 20th century. A spiritual revival swept through a large part of the [[Midwestern United States]] in the 1890s. Lutherans who were influenced by this fervor rejected several former beliefs as incompatible with their newfound spirituality. They rejected the idea of receiving the unconverted into full membership or admitting them to [[Eucharist|Communion]], replaced liturgical ceremonies with simple worship services, and formed new congregations to worship and serve according to these dictates of conscience. Five such Lutheran congregations from the [[United Norwegian Lutheran Church of America]] met in [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]], on December 17, 1900, and organized a synod named the Church of the Lutheran Brethren. Its Constitution was patterned after that of the [[Evangelical Lutheran Free Church of Norway|Lutheran Free Church of Norway]]. The Lutheran Bible School, forerunner of the current schools in [[Minnesota]], was founded in 1903 in [[Wahpeton, North Dakota]].
The CLBA emphasizes the foundational place of the [[Bible]], stating, "We believe the Bible is the [[Biblical inspiration|inspired]] Word of God and free from error. It is authoritative for faith and conduct." Other beliefs include the [[Trinity|triune Godhead]]; total depravity; the eternal Son-ship, [[Virgin birth of Jesus|Virgin Birth]], sinless life, [[substitutionary atonement]], bodily [[Resurrection of the dead#Resurrection of the dead in Christianity|resurrection]], and personal return of [[Jesus]]; [[infant baptism]]; and [[Eucharist|Holy Communion]]. It has been noted for practicing [[open communion]], teaching [[premillennialism]], and not having the laity receive absolution from the pastor.<ref>[http://clclutheran.org/atlanta/bibleclass/Lutheranchurches.pdf A Brief Study of the Lutheran Churches in America]</ref>
In addition to the denominational statement of faith, the church adheres to the following historic confessions: the [[Apostles' Creed]], [[Nicene Creed|Nicene]] and [[Athanasian Creed|Athanasian]] Creeds, the ''[[Augsburg Confession]]'', and [[Luther's Small Catechism]]. Its strong emphasis on [[Mission (Christian)|missions]] and [[evangelism]], its stand for non-liturgical worship and a church composed only of confessing Christians differentiates it from most Lutherans in America. The CLBA considers itself to be "Lutheran in theological tradition and evangelical in practice."
The Church of the Lutheran Brethren has 123 congregations with about 8,860 baptized members<ref>[http://www.lutheranworld.org/LWF_Documents/LWF-Statistics-2009.pdf LWF Statistics 2009] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604000000/http://www.lutheranworld.org/LWF_Documents/LWF-Statistics-2009.pdf |date=June 4, 2011 }}</ref> in the United States (114) and [[Canada]] (9), as well as about 1500 congregations in [[Cameroon]], [[Chad]], [[Japan]] and [[Taiwan]]. Its offices, the [[Lutheran Brethren Seminary]], the Lutheran Center For Christian Learning, and the [[Hillcrest Lutheran Academy]] are located in [[Fergus Falls, Minnesota]]. The CLBA has been led by President Paul Larson since 2014.
==Presidents of the CLBA== *Knut O. Lundeberg 1900–03 *J. J. Peterson 1903–04 *E. M. Broen 1904–05 *H. L. Westel 1905–08 *E. M. Broen 1908–14 *E. H. Gunhus 1914–24 *M. E. Sletta 1924–34 *E. H. Gunhus 1934–38 *M. E. Sletta 1938–48 *C. E. Walstad 1948–53 *D. A. Erickson 1953–54 *M. E. Sletta 1954–56 *D. A. Erickson 1956–68 *E. H. Strom 1968–86 *Robert M. Overgaard 1986–2001 *Joel Egge 2001–2014 *Paul Larson 2014–Present

Foreign mission churches total about 50,000 baptized[http://suburbanjournals.stltoday.com/articles/2010/05/04/west/special_feature/0505wc-faith0.txt St. Louis Today article: The sermon's in the mail] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120716235348/http://suburbanjournals.stltoday.com/articles/2010/05/04/west/special_feature/0505wc-faith0.txt |date=2012-07-16 }} | footnotes = }} The '''Church of the Lutheran Confession (CLC)''' is a conservative [[Christian]] religious body theologically adhering to confessional [[Lutheran]] doctrine. Founded in 1960 in Minnesota, it has approximately 85 [[parish|congregations]] in 24 U.S. states, and missions in [[Canada]], [[India]], [[Africa]], [[Nepal]], and [[Myanmar]]. The CLC maintains its headquarters at its ministerial college; [[Immanuel Lutheran College (Eau Claire)|Immanuel Lutheran High School, College & Seminary]] in [[Eau Claire, Wisconsin]]. ==Historical background== {{Lutheranism in the United States|expanded=synodical}} Various Lutheran congregations left their synods during the 1950s and were independent at first. They began meeting together in 1957.Tiefel, Mark. [http://minds.wisconsin.edu/bitstream/handle/1793/31790/Tiefel.pdf?sequence=2 Why Another School?: The Doctrinal History and Reasons for the Formation of Immanuel Lutheran High School, College, and Seminary]. December 10, 2008. p.26 The Church of the Lutheran Confession (CLC) was formed around the time of the break-up of the [[Evangelical Lutheran Synodical Conference of North America]] in 1963. The CLC was created primarily (though not solely) from congregations that broke away from the [[Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod]] (WELS) and the [[Evangelical Lutheran Synod]] (ELS) in a disagreement about the application of the principles of [[Christian]] fellowship (in this context, an agreement of a unity of belief). The CLC maintained that the WELS and ELS misapplied those principles by not breaking with the Synodical Conference and the [[Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod]] after they had publicly recognized doctrinal error within those bodies. While there were joint talks in the 1990s between the CLC and the WELS and ELS to resolve the dispute, no resolution was reached. Recently, the WELS and ELS have been in formal discussions with the CLC over doctrinal issues. The goal of these discussions is to restore fellowship with each other.{{cite web|title=Progress in doctrinal discussions|url=https://wels.net/progress-in-doctrinal-discussions/|publisher=Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod|date=September 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170510112150/https://wels.net/progress-in-doctrinal-discussions/|archivedate=May 10, 2017|access-date=December 12, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Doctrinal discussions continue between the CLC, the ELS, and WELS|url=https://wels.net/doctrinal-discussions-continue-between-the-clc-the-els-and-wels/|publisher=Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod|date=December 15, 2015|access-date=December 12, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Summary of the September meeting of the COP|url=https://wels.net/summary-of-the-september-meeting-of-the-cop/|publisher=Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod|date=October 4, 2016|access-date=December 12, 2017}} However, the 2017 CLC General Pastoral Conference has recommended that the 2018 CLC Convention reject the Joint Statement Regarding the Termination of Fellowship that was proposed in 2015 by the discussions.{{cite journal |date=Summer 2017 |title=Panorama - 2017 Church of the Lutheran Confession General Pastoral Conference Recommendation to the 2018 Church of the Lutheran Confession Convention |url=http://clclutheran.org/library/jtheo_arch/jt-2017-vol-057-num-02.pdf#page=36 |journal=Church of the Lutheran Confession's Journal of Theology |volume=57 |issue=2 |pages=36–38 |access-date=December 12, 2017 }} ==Beliefs and practice== ===Core beliefs=== The CLC teaches that the Bible is the only authoritative source for doctrine. It subscribes to the Lutheran Confessions (the [[Book of Concord]], 1580) as an accurate presentation of what Scripture teaches. It is strongly linked to the concept of ''[[sola scriptura]]''—scripture alone, and its website states, "If it is not Scripture; it is not Lutheran." ===Ecumenical relations=== Fellowship between the CLC and other church groups is established only upon investigation and confirmation that both church groups hold complete unity in scriptural doctrine and practice. The CLC is currently in fellowship with several worldwide synods, some founded through mission work by the CLC. ==Publishing and publications== The CLC Bookhouse is the official publishing house for the CLC. It is devoted to publishing Christian literature and CLC related religious materials, as well as several CLC periodicals. The CLC Bookhouse also offers books and items from other publishing houses. CLC periodicals include: * ''The Lutheran Spokesman'' — the CLC's monthly family magazine * ''Ministry by Mail'' — printed and online sermons for CLC members at a distance from their church * ''The Journal of Theology'' — a quarterly theological magazine * ''The Witness'' — an e-newsletter CLC educational materials include: * ''God's Hand in our Lives'' — the CLC Sunday School Series * ''Learn From Me'' — an adult instruction manual ==Presidents== *Paul Albrecht 1961-1972 *Robert Reim 1972-1974 *Egbert Albrecht 1974-1982 *Daniel Fleischer 1982-2002 *John Schierenbeck 2002–2012 *Michael Eichstadt 2012–present ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.clclutheran.org The Church of the Lutheran Confession website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Church Of The Lutheran Confession}} [[Category:Lutheran denominations in North America]] [[Category:Lutheranism in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Lutheranism in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations based in Eau Claire, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Evangelical denominations in North America]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1960]] [[Category:1960 establishments in Minnesota]]

{{Infobox Christian denomination | icon = | icon_width = | icon_alt = | name = Eielsen Synod | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | imagewidth = | alt = | caption = | abbreviation = | main_classification = [[Lutheranism|Lutheran]] | orientation = | scripture = | theology = | polity = | governance = | structure = | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title1 = | leader_name1 = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | fellowships_type = | fellowships = | fellowships_type1 = | fellowships1 = | division_type = | division = | division_type1 = | division1 = | division_type2 = | division2 = | division_type3 = | division3 = | associations = | area = [[United States]] | language = | liturgy = | headquarters = | origin_link = | founder = [[Elling Eielsen]] | founded_date = 1846 | founded_place = [[Jefferson Prairie Settlement, Wisconsin]] | separated_from = | parent = | merger = | absorbed = | separations = [[Hauge Synod]] (1876) | merged_into = | defunct = | congregations_type = | congregations = | members = | ministers_type = | ministers = | missionaries = | churches = | hospitals = | nursing_homes = | aid = | primary_schools = | secondary_schools = | tax_status = | tertiary = | other_names = Evangelical Lutheran Church in America | publications = | website = | slogan = | logo = | footnotes = }} The '''Eielsen Synod''' (originally named the '''Evangelical Lutheran Church in America''') was a [[Lutheran]] [[church body]]. It was founded in 1846 at [[Jefferson Prairie Settlement]], [[Wisconsin]] by a group of [[Haugean|Haugean Lutherans]] led by [[Elling Eielsen]].
==Background== There were church splits in 1848 and 1856. In 1876 the synod numbered 24 pastors, 59 congregations, and 7,500 members. That year a major split occurred and many of the clergymen and congregations left the Eielsen Synod and organized the [[Hauge Synod]]. Elling Eielsen and his supporters continued the synod under the 1846 church constitution in [[Jackson, Minnesota|Jackson]], [[Minnesota]].
The Eielsen Synod emphasized the importance of repentance, conversion, and lay preaching. It opposed ritualism, formal worship, clerical vestments, and clerical authority. The Eielsen Synod had 1,500 members in ten churches in 1953. By 1971, it had declined to 75 members scattered among churches in [[French Lake Township, Minnesota|French Lake]] and [[Jackson, Minnesota]]; [[Centerville, South Dakota]]; and [[Taylor, Wisconsin|Taylor]] and [[Lodi, Wisconsin]].<ref>[http://www.adherents.com/Na/Na_281.html ''Major Branches of Religions Ranked by Number of Adherents'' (Adherents.com)]</ref>
In 1985, there were approximately 50 members at just three churches: Stall Norwegian Church in [[Jackson, Minnesota]]; Bethania Lutheran in [[Lodi, Wisconsin|Lodi]]/[[Eau Claire, Wisconsin]]; and Immanuel in [[French Lake Township, Wright County, Minnesota|French Lake, Minnesota]]. Immanuel is now an independent Lutheran church. <ref>[http://www.cokatomuseum.org/immanuel.html ''A Synod Of One: The Story Of Immanuel Lutheran Church'' (Karen Christofferson. "In The Midst Of" December 1999. V. 19 No. 4)]</ref> The Eielson Synod is still in existence with a minister ordained on May 10, 2008 by the presiding president of Bethania ELCA-Eielson Church. Martin Leroy Bystol was the active President of such ministry of the Eielsen Synod until his death. Rev Orvin L. Bystol is an ordained minister and resides in Eau Claire, where the church is located.

[[Community of Protestant Churches in Europe]] | area = [[Estonia]] | congregations = 164 | members = 180,000 (2014) {{cite web|title=Churches in Estonia|url=https://www.lutheranworld.org/country/estonia|website=lutheranworld.org|publisher=Lutheran World Federation|accessdate=February 16, 2016}} | footnotes = | website = [http://www.eelk.ee/ http://www.eelk.ee/] }} {{Lutheranism in the United States|expanded=mainline}} [[File:Tallinn Cathedral from S.JPG|thumb|[[St Mary's Cathedral, Tallinn]]]] [[File:Tartu_Jaani_Church_2007_13.jpg|thumb|[[St. John's Church, Tartu]]]] [[File:Aleksandri-kirik2.jpg|thumb|Alexander's Cathedral|[[Alexander's Cathedral|Alexander Cathedral, Narva]]]] The '''Estonian Evangelical Lutheran Church''' (Estonian: ''Eesti Evangeelne Luterlik Kirik'', abbreviated ''EELK'') is a [[Lutheran]] church in [[Estonia]]. EELC is member of the [[Lutheran World Federation]] and belongs to the [[Community of Protestant Churches in Europe]]. It is also a member of the [[Porvoo Communion]], putting it in [[full communion]] with the [[Church of England]] and other Anglican churches in Europe. ==History== The Estonian Evangelical Lutheran Church (EELC) was constituted in 1949, when the previous church hierarchy, ''Eesti Evangeeliumi Luteriusu Kirik'', headed by [[bishop]] [[Johan Kõpp]], had escaped to [[Sweden]] in 1944. When the [[Soviet Union]] invaded Estonia in 1940, most Christian organizations were dissolved, church property was confiscated, theologians were exiled to [[Siberia]], and religious education programs were outlawed. [[World War II]] later brought devastation to many church buildings. It was not until 1988 that church activities were renewed when a movement for religious tolerance began in the Soviet Union. Although women had studied [[theology]] at [[Tartu University]] in the 1920s and some had sought ordination as priests, it was not until 1967 that the first woman, [[Laine Villenthal]], was ordained. In 2014, the church reported that there were 169 men and 43 women serving as ministers. ==Leadership== The Church of Estonia is episcopal in polity, and is led by five bishops, including the archbishop who serves as the [[Primate (bishop)|Primate]].Bishops named [http://www.eelk.ee/kirik/meie-vaimulikud/piiskopid/ here] (Estonian). The archbishop has overall control, and under his authority there are four jurisdictions, each with its own Bishop. {| class="wikitable" |- ! | Diocese ! | Cathedral ! | See ! | Current bishop |- | Archdiocese of Tallinn | [[St Mary's Cathedral, Tallinn]] | [[Tallinn]] | [[Urmas Viilma]] ''([[Primate (bishop)|Primate of Estonia]])'' |- | Diocese of the Western and Northern Region | [[Haapsalu Castle|St Nicholas Cathedral, Haapsalu]] | Haapsalu | Tiit Salumäe |- | Diocese of the Southern Region | | [[Tartu]] | Joel Luhamets |- | Extra-Estonian Diocese | | [[Canada]] | Vacant |} Following the retirement of [[Andres Põder]] as archbishop, the current archbishop is Urmas Viilma, consecrated on 2 February 2015.Consecration date stated [http://www.eelk.ee/kirik/meie-vaimulikud/piiskopid/peapiiskop-urmas-viilma/ here] (Estonian). During the Soviet occupation of Estonia, the Archbishop went into exile, which resulted in the formation of a parallel church, the Estonian Evangelical Lutheran Church Abroad. Until 2010 this body was independent, with its own Archbishop based in Canada. In 2010 the two churches reunited, and the former overseas church became a [[diocese]] of the Estonian Evangelical Lutheran Church, known as the Extra-Estonian Diocese ({{lang-et|Välis-Eesti piiskopkond}}).Details of reunion at [https://www.oikoumene.org/en/member-churches/estonian-evangelical-lutheran-church World Council of Churches] website. ==Archbishops== *Jakob Kukk (1921-1933) *Hugo Bernhard Rahamägi (1934-1939) *[[Johan Kõpp]] (1939-1944) *Jaan Kiivit seenior (1949-1967) *Alfred Tooming (1967-1977) *Edgar Hark (1978-1986) *[[Kuno Pajula]] (1987-1994) *[[Jaan Kiivit Jr.]] (1994-2005) *[[Andres Põder]] (2005-2014) *[[Urmas Viilma]] (2015-Present) ==Membership== As of February 2009, the EELC reported approximately 160,000 baptized members and the EELC Abroad (based in Canada) reported approximately 8,000 baptized members.[http://www.lutheranworld.org/LWF_Documents/LWF-Statistics-2009.pdf LWF Statistics 2009] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100821080424/http://www.lutheranworld.org/LWF_Documents/LWF-Statistics-2009.pdf |date=August 21, 2010 }} A previous figure broke down the EELC Abroad into 3,508 members with 12 clergy in the USA and 5,536 members with 11 clergy in Canada.[http://clclutheran.org/atlanta/bibleclass/Lutheranchurches.pdf A Brief Study of the Lutheran Churches in America] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101121161735/http://clclutheran.org/atlanta/bibleclass/Lutheranchurches.pdf |date=2010-11-21 }} In 2014, the Lutheran World Federation reported the number of registered members as being 180,000.{{cite web|title=Churches in Estonia|url=https://www.lutheranworld.org/country/estonia|website=lutheranworld.org|publisher=Lutheran World Federation|accessdate=February 16, 2016}} The church reported that it had served 143,895 communicants. ==Social issues== The church has both theologically conservative and liberal members.{{Cite web|url=http://news.postimees.ee/3003191/no-obvious-option-for-lutheran-archbishop|title=No obvious option for Lutheran archbishop - Local News - Estonian news in English|website=Postimees|access-date=2016-05-25}} The church does ordain women to the priesthood, unlike the more conservative [[Evangelical Lutheran Church of Latvia]] and [[Evangelical Lutheran Church of Lithuania]]. In an interview, Archbishop [[Urmas Viilma]] stated that the church allows women ordination and "will continue to do so". The church also disapproves homosexual unions, believing marriage is the sacred union of a man and a woman. It only allows celibate gay ministers to be ordained. However, Archbishop Viilma did state that if same-sex marriage is legalized in the country, "then the church will clearly need to redefine itself", but he also stated that "we clearly interpret the Bible to say that practicing homosexuality is sin...but we all are equal in God’s eyes an welcome in church."{{cite web|last1=Koch|first1=Tuuli|title=All have sinned|url=http://news.postimees.ee/3007237/all-have-sinned|website=postimees.ee|publisher=Postimes|accessdate=April 18, 2016}} The Lutherans leaned toward opposing the death penalty, although they took no official stance, and the church does not have a committee "dealing with social-political questions".{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WDrihdh-TiIC&pg=PA214&lpg=PA214&dq=Estonian+Lutherans+on+social+issues&source=bl&ots=-YQb7WgmBk&sig=PlEDvD4nJCPSUJWb1a70FdR06NU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiXyPGw4efMAhUm3IMKHY7yDwIQ6AEIQzAG#v=onepage&q=Estonian%2520Lutherans%2520on%2520social%2520issues&f=false|title=The Politics of Religion in Russia and the New States of Eurasia|last=Bourdeaux|first=Michael|date=1995-01-01|publisher=M.E. Sharpe|isbn=9781563243561|language=en}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * https://web.archive.org/web/20040803083318/http://www.eelk.ee/english.php * The History Files [http://www.historyfiles.co.uk/MainChurchesEurope.htm Churches of Estonia] * [https://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&geocode=&q=59.438065,24.745928&sll=37.0625,-95.677068&sspn=42.495706,93.076172&ie=UTF8&ll=59.147769,26.312256&spn=3.454343,15.820312&z=7 Map of Church in Tallinn] * [https://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&geocode=&q=58.37181,26.715815&sll=58.370741,26.718332&sspn=1.765965,5.817261&doflg=ptk&ie=UTF8&ll=57.715885,22.434082&spn=7.200081,23.269043&z=6 Map of Church in Tartu] {{Porvoo Communion}} {{Lutheran World Federation Churches}} [[Category:Lutheran World Federation members]] [[Category:Tallinn]] [[Category:Lutheranism in Estonia]] [[Category:Members of the World Council of Churches]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1949]] [[Category:Lutheran denominations established in the 20th century]] [[Category:1940s establishments in Estonia]] [[Category:1949 establishments in the Soviet Union]] {{Estonia-stub}} {{Lutheran-stub}}
